(TO BE READ WITH EDITORIAL)
The following editorial was originally presented by Radio Station WJAY in
Mullins, South Carolina. It has been edited, and it is being distributed
to member stations by the South Carolina Broadcasters Association.
7^
The Carnegie Commission on Educational TV has spent a half-million
dollars on just putting the proposal into a tangible form. A half-million
dollars "ain’t hay", even to the Carnegie Foundation. And, the idea has
President Johnson7s unqualified approval. And, it does not cost the Federal
Government one penny. The money to pay for the thing would come from a
small tax on TV set purchases. That would provide $ 104-mi 1.1 ion a year to
operate the thing. The thing is a new television network - one that would
have NO commercials. The new television network would have 380 stations,
coast-to-coast — all paid for out of the tax on your next TV set purchase.
Who would run the thing? Six men would be appointed by the President, con¬
firmed by the Senate - and, these six men would get six more. The twelve
men would run this TV network of 380 stations on the $104-million collected
from the special tax on TV set purchases. Then, the public on the public7s
own television network would get "good" non-commercial programs, programs
designed to educate you like the Carnegie Foundation wants you to be edu¬
cated. Perhaps the President, whoever he is at the moment, would have some
small say-so about the education you would get on the public7s own non¬
commercial television network. Why wouldn7t the President have a say-so?
After all, the President appoints six of the men who run the thing —
approved by the Senate, of course - which makes that absolutely non¬
political and non-partisan - and, these six get six more which makes that
absolutely unbiased about the war in Vietnam, the debt ceiling, your Social
Security tax which gets bigger while the dollar gets smaller. Medicare’s
expansion. Civil Rights, the United Nations, the next deal with Moscow —
you see that the six men chosen by another six would assure you education
on these things that is absolutely unbiased.
Who started this thing? Dr. James R. Killian, Jr. is chairman of
the Carnegie Commission on Educational Television. Dr. Killian is, also,
chairman of the board of Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Massachu¬
setts Institute of Technology is, also, the former base of operations of
Dr. Walt W. Rostow, chairman of the President’s National Security Council,
appointed by the late President Kennedy and retained by President Johnson.
Dr. Rostow is the author of the "Russia is mellowing" theory on which U-S
foreign policy is based and by which the United States proposes to trade
with the Reds while they kill off U-S young men at the rate of 8,000 a year
(currently) and kill off U-S currency value at the rate of $24-billion a
year - $24-billion, spelled with a "B".
Dr. Killian, the Carnegie Foundation, President Johnson, Dr. Ros¬
tow have this thing all worked out except for one thing. They need a bill
passed by Congress to tax your next TV set. If Congress passes that bill,
you’ve had it — you, and your children. A Federal Government TV network
of 380 stations would eventually control your decisions just like Hitler
controlled the German people’s decisions. It does seem like such a good
idea, until you look again. The Carnegie Foundation has made its move.
It’s your move, now.
